H0.text: The heat from the fire travels through the ground and heats the ground around the people, allowing people sitting around a campfire to feel the heat without touching the fire.

H1.text: The heat from the fire is conducted through air molecules to the people, allowing people sitting around a campfire to feel the heat without touching the fire.

H2.text: The heat from the fire rises in the air and then settles around the people, allowing those sitting around a campfire to feel the heat without touching the fire.

H3.text: The heat from the fire radiates from the fire to the people sitting around a campfire, allowing them to feel the heat without touching the fire.

A4.text: In this case the heat has made its way through the space between the fire and the thermometer, by the process termed radiation.

A5.text: a portion of the air, passing through and near the fire, has become heated, and has carried up the chimney the temperature acquired from the fire.

A6.text: Thermal radiation is a phenomenon that can burn skin and ignite flammable materials.

A7.text: Thermal radiation is one of the fundamental mechanisms of heat transfer, along with conduction and convection.
